section.title: Named properties and special subsets of real numbers

subsection.title: Special subsets of the real numbers
subsection.p: For our purposes, the real numbers consists of all possible decimals. These include whole numbers, both positive and negative, fractions, simple decimals like 1.25, repeating decimals like 1.333\ldots=\frac43 and irrational numbers like \sqrt2 and \pi.

We have some special notation that is used with the real numbers:
\N, the natural numbers, is the set of all nonnegative integers: \{0, 1, 2, 3,\ldots\}.
\Z, the integers, consists of \{0, \pm1, \pm2, \pm3, \ldots\}.
\Q, the rationals, is the set of all fractions: \frac mn where m and n are integers with n\not=0.
\R is the set of all real numbers, that is, ordinary decimals.

subsection.title: Basic definitions
subsection.p:
Summation notation is a compact form for writing sums. It is written with three pieces. \[ \sum_{\fbox{k=1}}^\fbox{5} \fbox{2k} \] The part below the greek letter sigma (\Sigma) tells us to start with k=1. We increment k by 1 until we get to the value above the sigma. In this case we let k take on the values 1, 2, 3, 4, 5. We next substitute those values of k into the expression to the right of the sigma successively and take the sum all of the resulting terms. Here is a table of the resulting values:
k \amp\amp 2k 1 \amp\amp 2 2 \amp\amp 4 3 \amp\amp 6 4 \amp\amp 8 5 \amp\amp 10
which evaluates to 2+4+6+8+10=30 and so we write \sum_{k=1}^5 2k=30. The variable k is called the index of summation. The number above the sigma is called the limit of summation. The example shows us how to write a sum of even numbers. We can write the sum of odd numbers, too. \sum_{k=1}^8 (2k-1)=1+3+5+7+9+11+13+15=64 . It is not necessary to use k as a variable or to start the summation at k=1. It is easy to verify that \sum_{k=1}^8(2k-1)=\sum_{l=0}^7(2l+1)=64 .
The number above the sigma can also be written as a variable:
\sum_{k=1}^n a_k=a_1+a_2+\cdots+a_{n-1}+a_n \sum_{k=0}^n a_kb_k=a_0b_0+a_1b_1+a_2b_2+\cdots+a_{n-1}b_{n-1}+a_nb_n \sum_{k=1}^n (2k-1) = 1+3+5+7+\cdots+(2n-1)

subsection.p:
The summands can be symbolic, too. If f(x) is any function, we may write
\sum_{i=1}^r f(i)=f(1)+f(2)+\cdots+f(r-1)+f(r)

subsection.title: Alternating sums
subsection.p:
A sum is alternating if the signs of consecutive terms are alternate between positive and negative.
An example: 1-2+3-4+5. These sums appear frequently enough to have this special name. They are easy to write using summation notation because of a simple fact:
(-1)^k= \begin{cases} 1 \amp \text{if \(k\) is even}\\ -1 \amp \text{if \(k\) is odd} \end{cases}
We can then write \sum_{k=1}^6 (-1)^k k^2=-1+4-9+16-25+36=21 . We can interchange the order of the signs by adding (or subtracting) one to the exponent of -1: \sum_{k=1}^6 (-1)^{k+1} k^2=1-4+9-16+25-36=-21.

subsection.title: Manipulation with summation notation identities
subsection.p: Summation notation is more that mere shorthand. There are rules of manipulation that are quite useful.

For any constant c,
\sum_{k=1}^n c=\underbrace{c+c+\cdots+c+c}_{n \textrm{ summands}}=nc
and
\sum_{k=1}^n ca_k =ca_1+\cdots+ca_n =c(a_1+\cdots+a_n) =c\sum_{k=1}^n a_k
The process of the last equation is sometimes referred to as pulling a constant across the summation sign.

In addition,
\sum_{k=1}^n(a_k+b_k)= \sum_{k=1}^na_k+\sum_{k=1}^nb_k,\\ \sum_{k=1}^n(a_k-b_k)= \sum_{k=1}^na_k-\sum_{k=1}^nb_k
and
\sum_{k=0}^na_k= \sum_{k=t}^{n+t}a_{k-t}
The last identity is sometimes called shifting the index of summation.

example.p:
Suppose we want to evaluate the sum of the first n positive integers. In other words, we want to find
s_n=1+2+\cdots+n=\sum_{k=1}^nk.
If we are convinced that \sum_{k=1}^n(2k-1)=1+3+5+\cdots+2n-1=n^2, then
n^2\amp =\sum_{k=1}^n(2k-1) \amp =\sum_{k=1}^n(2k)-\sum_{k=1}^n1 \amp =2\sum_{k=1}^nk-n \amp =2s_n-n
which yields
s_n=\frac12n(n+1).

statement.p:
Evaluate the following sums
\sum_{j=1}^5 2j
\sum_{k=1}^5 k(k-1)
\sum_{i=0}^4 2^i
\sum_{\ell=1}^3\ell^2+\frac1\ell
\sum_{j=1}^5 ij
Evaluate \sum_{k=0}^n 2^k for n=1,2,3,4. Find a simple expression that works for any n. Justify your answer.

solution.p:
\begin{array}{cc} n \amp \sum_{k=0}^n 2^k\\ \hline 1 \amp 3\\ 2 \amp 7\\ 3\amp 15\\ 4\amp 31 \end{array}
We note that each answer is one less than a power of 2. This leads to the equation \[ \sum_{k=0}^n 2^k=2^{n+1}-1. \] To justify the equation we note that \[ 2(\sum_{k=0}^n 2^k)=\sum_{k=0}^n 2^{k+1}=\sum_{k=1}^{n+1} 2^k =\bigl(\sum_{k=0}^{n+1} 2^k\bigr) -1 \] so we get the sum for a given value on n by doubling the value for n-1 and adding 1.

subsection.title: Double summations
subsection.p: Sometimes it is useful to have a formula with two summations, each with its own index of summation. It is interpreted in the following way: \[ \sum_{i=1}^m \sum_{j=1}^n f(i,j)= \sum_{i=1}^m \bigl(\sum_{j=1}^n f(i,j)\bigr) \] and so, for example, \[ \sum_{i=1}^3 \sum_{j=1}^2 i^j=\sum_{i=1}^3 (i^1+i^2)=(1+1)+(2+4)+(3+9)=20 \]

Another way of looking at these double summations \sum_{i=1}^m \sum_{j=1}^n f(i,j) is that it is the sum of f(i,j) as i takes on values from 1 to m and j takes on values from 1 to n. Clearly there are mn summands altogether.

subsection.title: Basic Definitions
subsection.p: In any such right triangle, the angle \theta is necessarily acute. We extend the definition of the trigonometric functions to other angles by using the unit circle (centre at \vec 0=(0,0) and radius r=1). For any angle \theta, draw the radius of the unit circle that makes an angle \theta with the positive x-axis. The coordinates of the point where this radius meets the circle are (\cos(\theta),\sin(\theta)). Note that when \theta is acute, the two definitions coincide.
Since the point (\cos(\theta),\sin(\theta)) is on the unit circle, its distance to the origin (0,0) is 1. This means \[ \cos^2(\theta) + \sin^2(\theta) =1 \textrm{ for any angle } \theta \]

subsection.title: The law of cosines
subsection.p: In the right triangle above, the angle opposite the side labelled c is an right angle, and the Pythagorean theorem says c^2=a^2+b^2. The law of cosines extends this theorem to triangles with any angle opposite the side labelled c.

statement.p: If a triangle (as in the figure below) has sides of lengths a, b and c, and the angle at the vertex opposite c is \theta, then \[ c^2=a^2+b^2-2ab\,\cos\theta \]

proof.p: Note that since a and b are interchangeable in the picture, there is no loss of generality to assume a \le b. We prove the law of cosines by dropping a perpendicular to the side b:
The perpendicular has length h and splits side b into two pieces of lengths b_1 and b_2.

Now we have the following identities:
b=b_1+b_2
a^2=b_1^2 + h^2
c^2 = b_2^2 + h^2
b_1=a\cos(\theta)
which gives the equations
\begin{array}{rl} c^2 \amp=b_2^2+h^2\\ \amp=(b-b_1)^2+(a^2-b_1^2)\\ \amp=b^2 -2bb_1 + b_1^2 +a^2-b_1^2\\ \amp=a^2+b^2-2bb_1\\ \amp=a^2+b^2-2ab\cos(\theta) \end{array}
We have cheated a little by assuming that the perpendicular divides b into two pieces. In fact if \theta\gt\frac\pi2 then the picture looks like

Now we have
a^2=b_1^2+h^2
c^2=(b+b_1)^2+h^2
b_1=-a\cos(\theta) (remember that \cos(\theta)\lt0 when \frac\pi 2\lt\theta\lt\pi)
which gives
\begin{array}{rl} c^2 \amp= (b+b_1)^2+h^2\\ \amp= (b+b_1)^2+(a^2-b_1^2)\\ \amp= b^2+2bb_1+a^2\\ \amp= a^2+b^2-2ab\cos(\theta) \end{array}
In principle there is another possibility:

In this case we a \gt b, contrary to our assumption that a\leq b. Nonetheless we could use the argument:
a^2=(b+b_1)^2 + h^2
c^2 = b_1^2 + h^2
b+b_1=a\cos(\theta)
and can deduce c^2=a^2+b^2-2ab\cos(\theta) in a manner similar that used in the previous cases.

subsection.title: The graphs of \sin(x) and \cos(x)
subsection.p: The graphs of the trigonometric functions are revealing. First, here is the graph of the function \sin(x):
Notice that \sin(x) is positive in this range precisely when 0\lt x\lt\pi.
Here is the graph of \cos(x):

Notice that the function \cos(x) is decreasing for 0\le x\le\pi. By decreasing we mean that if x_1 \lt x_2, then \cos(x_1) \gt \cos(x_2) (or, more intuitively, the function goes downhill as we go from left to right). There is an important implication from this: if y=\cos(x) for some x with 0\le x\le\pi, then for any for any other x' in the same range, we have \cos(x') \gt y (when x'\lt x) or \cos(x') \lt y (when x'\gt x). In particular this means that for any given y_0, there is at most one x_0 with 0\le x_0\le\pi so that y_0=\cos(x_0). In fact, the intermediate value theorem from the Calculus implies that for any y_0 satisfying -1\leq y_0 \leq 1 there is some x_0 satisfying 0\le x_0\le\pi so that y_0=\cos(x_0).

This may be visualized as follows: pick any y_0 between -1 and 1. From that value on the y-axis, go horizontally until you hit the graph of the function y=\cos(x) and then drop down to the x-axis at the point x_0. This value x_0 is the unique one for which \cos(x_0)=y_0.

subsection.title: Parallelograms
subsection.p: A parallelogram is a quadrilateral with opposite sides parallel. Here is an example of one filled in yellow:
The parallelogram law relates the lengths of sides of a parallelogram to the lengths of the diagonals.

statement.p: If a parallelogram has sides of length a and b, and c and d are the lengths of the two diagonals, then \[ c^2+d^2=2a^2+2b^2 \] In other words, the sum of the squares of the sides is the sum of the squares of the diagonals.

proof.p: The proof can be seen from the following two figures. Applying the law of cosines to the first figure gives \[ c^2=a^2+b^2-2ab\cos(\theta)\tag1 \] while applying it to the second figure gives \[ d^2=a^2+b^2-2ab\cos(\pi-\theta)= a^2+b^2+2ab\cos(\theta)\tag2 \]

subsection.title: The addition formulas for \sin(x) and \cos(x)
subsection.p: Suppose we know \sin(\alpha), \cos(\alpha), \sin(\beta), and \cos(\beta). We wish to find formulas to compute \sin(\alpha+\beta), and \cos(\alpha+\beta). The following figure shows us how to do the computation.

The points A=(\cos(\alpha),\sin(\alpha)), B=\cos(\alpha+\beta),\sin(\alpha+\beta)) and (0,1) all lie on a circle with centre at the origin and radius 1. These three points are joined by a line to the origin \vec 0. Drop perpendiculars from B to the line joining \vec0 and (1,0) and also to the line joining and \vec0 and A. The points F and E are where the perpendiculars meet the respective lines. The line joining B and E is extended until it meets the line joining \vec 0 and (1,0) at D=(d,0).
Now we compute the area of the yellow triangle in two different ways and equate the results.

Consider the lengths of these lines:
\|BF\|=\sin(\alpha+\beta) (from triangle \vec0 B F)
\|\vec 0 D\|=d
\|\vec 0 E\|=d\cos(\alpha)=\cos(\beta) (from triangles \vec0DE and \vec0BE, which implies that d=\frac{\cos(\beta)}{\cos(\alpha)})
\|BD\|=\|BE\|+\|ED\|=\sin(\beta)+d\sin(\alpha) (from triangles \vec0BE and \vec0DE)

On the one hand, twice the area of the yellow triangle is \[ \|BF\|\,\|\vec0 D\| = d\sin(\alpha+\beta) \]
On the other hand, twice the triangle area is also \[ \|\vec0 E\|\, \|BD\|=d\cos(\alpha)\left(\sin(\beta)+d\sin(\alpha)\right) \]
Equating the two values we get \[ \sin(\alpha+\beta)=\cos(\alpha)\sin(\beta)+d\cos(\alpha)\sin(\alpha) =\cos(\alpha)\sin(\beta)+\cos(\beta)\sin(\alpha) \]

Note that, from the right triangle \vec0 E D, the angle at D is \frac\pi2-\alpha, and then from the right triangle B F D the angle at B is \alpha. We use this to compute some more lengths:
\|DF\| = \|BD\|\sin(\alpha)=(\sin(\beta)+d\sin(\alpha))\sin(\alpha)
\|\vec0 F\|=\cos(\alpha+\beta)
Now we have
\begin{array}{rl} \|\vec0 F\| \amp= \|\vec0 D\|- \|DF\|\\ \cos(\alpha+\beta) \amp=d-(\sin(\beta)+d\sin(\alpha))\sin(\alpha)\\ \amp=d-\sin(\beta)\sin(\alpha)-d\, \sin^2(\alpha)\\ \amp= d(1-\sin^2(\alpha))-\sin(\beta)\sin(\alpha)\\ \amp=d\,\cos^2(\alpha)-\sin(\beta)\sin(\alpha)\\ \amp= \cos(\beta)\cos(\alpha)-\sin(\beta)\sin(\alpha) \end{array}
and so we have \[ \sin(\alpha+\beta)=\sin(\alpha)\cos(\beta)+\cos(\alpha)\sin(\beta)\\ \cos(\alpha+\beta)=\cos(\alpha)\cos(\beta)-\sin(\alpha)\sin(\beta) \]

subsection.title: The law of sines
subsection.p: Suppose a triangle has sides of lengths a, b and c. Let \alpha, \beta, and \gamma be the angles opposite a, b and c respectively. In addition, let the vertices of the triangle be labelled A, B and C at the angles \alpha, \beta, and \gamma respectively. Our picture looks like this:
It is pretty obvious that the sides with longer length will have larger angles opposite. The law of sines makes this relationship precise.

proof.p: With no loss of generality, we may assume that \alpha is the largest angle. It may be acute or obtuse, but \beta and \gamma are definitely acute. That implies that we may drop a perpendicular from A that will divide the angle \alpha into \alpha_1 and \alpha_2 the side opposite into segments with lengths a_1 and a_2.

This is a calculator for computing the reduced row echelon form of a matrix. In the box below
Set the value of rows to the number of rows.
Set the value of cols to the number of columns.
Enter the matrix entries as a comma-separated list. The placement on lines is not important as long as there are rows*cols entries.
